Question: filtering algorithm trouble: :public static String filterPhoneNumber(String phoneNumber) {    Character[] characters = new Character[phoneNumber.length()];    if (characters.length > 9)    {        for (int i = 0; i < characters.length; i++)        {            if (characters[i] != ' ')            {                characters[i] = phoneNumber.charAt(i);            } else            {                Log.d("asd", "wrroooonggggggggg");            }        }    }    return phoneNumber;}Im trying to filter empty chars in the number, but when 2 or more empty chars are found in the string, it removes only the first. 
Please using this api: String.getBytes.
Answer: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION

API: String.getBytes()
CODE: 
public static String filterPhoneNumber(String phoneNumber) {
    byte[] bytes = phoneNumber.getBytes();
    StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
    for (byte b : bytes) {
        if (b != ' ') {
            sb.append((char) b);
        }
    }
    return sb.toString();
}

EXPLANATION: 
This code uses the String.getBytes() method to convert the input string into a byte array. Each byte in the array corresponds to a character in the string. We then iterate over the byte array and convert each byte back to a character using the (char) cast. If the byte is not a space character (ASCII value 32), we append it to the StringBuilder. Finally, we return the string representation of the StringBuilder. This effectively removes all spaces from the input string.

Note: This code assumes that the input string only contains ASCII characters. If the input string contains characters outside the ASCII range, the byte array will contain non-printable characters and the code may not work as expected.
